Authors: Zhou J., Lin Z., Luo C., Wang X.
Title: Potential structural traps associated with lower carboniferous salt in the northern Tarim Basin, NW China
Affiliations: Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1131, Wushan, Guangzhou 510640, China; Northwest Bureau of Petroleum Geol., CINOPEC, Urumqi 83001, China; Research Inst. of Petroleum Explor., CINOPEC, Jingzhou, Hubei 434100, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, J., Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1131, Wushan, Guangzhou 510640, China; Lin, Z., Northwest Bureau of Petroleum Geol., CINOPEC, Urumqi 83001, China; Luo, C., Research Inst. of Petroleum Explor., CINOPEC, Jingzhou, Hubei 434100, China; Wang, X., Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1131, Wushan, Guangzhou 510640, China
Abstract: In the Aixieke-Santamu area of the northern Tarim Basin (NW China), 45 relatively low amplitude structures related to the plastic flow of Lower Carboniferous salt have been discovered in the Lower Carboniferous Kalashayi Formation and the Middle-Upper Triassic Akekule and Halahatan Formations. Three small hydrocarbon accumulations have so far been located at the margins of a Lower Carboniferous salt body (measuring about 55km × 75km and 115-225m thick, controlled by wells and 2D and 3D seismic sections). In this paper, we consider the development of this salt body and discuss possible reasons why vertical diapirs are absent from the study area. We attempt to develop a model of salt flow and we investigate the relationship between salt flow and the occurrence of oil and gas traps. Using recently-acquired high-resolution 2D and 3D seismic profiles, we show that the Lower Carboniferous salt has undergone three separate phases of plastic flow. At the end of the Early Permian, the salt flowed southwards by 2.0-2.8 km; then, during the Late Triassic - Early Jurassic, it flowed in the same direction by 1.0-1.8 km; and finally at the end of the Tertiary, it flowed northwards by 0.6-1.5 km. These movements resulted in the formation of various types of structural trap in the Kalashayi, Akekule and Halahatan Formations including salt ridge anticlines, domes and marginal troughs. Salt ridge and salt edge low-amplitude anticlines are probably the most important targets for future hydrocarbon exploration.
Index Keywords: Catchments; Geographical regions; Hydrocarbons; Mathematical models; Salts; Anticline structures; Hydrocarbon extrapolation; Crude petroleum; Carboniferous; deformation; hydrocarbon entrapment; salt; seismic survey; stratigraphy; Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East; Tarim Basin; Xinjiang Uygur

Authors: Zhu H., Xu Z.F., Wang H., Li B.G.
Title: Tropical rain forest fragmentation and its ecological and species diversity changes in southern Yunnan
Affiliations: Xishuangbanna Trop. Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xue Fu Road 88, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, H., Xishuangbanna Trop. Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xue Fu Road 88, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China; Xu, Z.F., Xishuangbanna Trop. Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xue Fu Road 88, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China; Wang, H., Xishuangbanna Trop. Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xue Fu Road 88, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China; Li, B.G., Xishuangbanna Trop. Botanical Garden, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xue Fu Road 88, Kunming 650223, Yunnan, China
Abstract: Three fragmented rain forests and one primary forest in southern Yunnan were plotted. The microclimate and soil conditions of these forests were also studied. The following conclusions were drawn: (1) The microclimatic differences between inside and outside forest are less in the fragmented forests than in the primary forest, which indicates that the buffer effects to climatic change have been reduced in the fragmented forests. The soil has deteriorated to some extent due to forest fragmentation. (2) In species composition, especially the abundance of some species and the dominant ranks of some families have changed with fragmentation. Barringtonia macrostachya, the most dominant species in the control primary forest, disappeared from the fragmented forests, while Antiaris toxicaria, which is a characteristic but not dominant species in the primary forest, is dominant in fragmented forests. (3) The total number of species per plot was reduced in the fragmented forests and the more seriously disturbed the fragment was, the more the species richness diminished. (4) In life form spectra, the liana and microphanerophyte species increased, but epiphyte, megaphanerophyte, mesophanerophyte and chamaephyte species decreased in the fragmented forests. (5) The plant species diversity is generally lower in the fragmented forests than in the primary forest, although for some life forms it could be higher. (6) The tree species with small populations could be lost first in the process of rain forest fragmentation. (7) The heliophilous or pioneer tree species increased and the shade-tolerant species were reduced in the fragmented forests.
Author Keywords: Ecological factors; Rainforest fragments; Southern Yunnan of China; Species diversity
Index Keywords: community composition; habitat fragmentation; microclimate; rainforest; soil degradation; species diversity; species richness; Asia; China; Eurasia; Far East; Yunnan; Antiaris; Antiaris toxicaria; Barringtonia

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; New Mexico; Recodification and SIP renumbering of the New Mexico administrative code for Albuquerque/Bernalillo County
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the Governor of New Mexico on 5/2/2003, which revises the numbering and format of New Mexico's Albuquerque/Bernalillo County SIP and contains no substantive changes to these regulations. EPA is approving these revisions in accordance with the requirements of the CAAA. Titles/subjects in the approved regulations pertain to VOC, motor vehicle inspection, motor vehicle visible emissions, etc. This rule is effective on 2/28/2005, without further notice, unless the EPA receives adverse written comment by 1/31/2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Virginia; Excess volatile organic compound and nitrogen oxides emissions fee rule
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Commonwealth of Virginia's SIP for ozone. The rule requires major stationary sources of VOC and NOx in the Virginia portion of the Metropolitan Washington DC. Severe ozone nonattainment area to pay a fee to the state if the area fails to attain the 1-hr NAAQS for ozone by 11/5/2005. The fee must be paid starting in 2006, and in each calendar year thereafter, until the area is redesignated to attainment for the pollutant ozone. This rule is effective on 2/28/2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; District of Columbia; VOC emission standards for portable fuel containers and spouts
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the District of Columbia SIP. Specifically, EPA is approving new emission standards for portable fuel containers and spouts sold, supplied, offered for sale, or manufactured for sale in the District of Columbia. EPA is approving the new portable fuel container and spouts standards to reduce emissions of VOC in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 2/28/2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; District of Columbia; excess volatile organic compound and nitrogen oxides emissions fee rule
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the District of Columbia SIP for ozone. The rule requires major stationary sources of VOC and NOx in the District, which is part of the Metropolitan Washington DC Severe Ozone Nonattainment Area, to pay a fee to the District if the area fails to attain the 1-hr NAAQS for ozone by 11/5/2005. The fee must be paid starting in 2006, and in each calendar year thereafter, until the area is redesignated to attainment for the pollutant ozone. This rule is effective on 2/28/2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government & policy concentrates: DOE offers $100 million for CO2 sequestration
Abstract: DOE has offered 4 yr worth of grants totaling up to $25 million/yr to help build a national infrastructure to support sequestration of CO2, which makes up 81% of US greenhouse gas emissions. The grants would continue a program that DOE began 2 yr ago involving some 160 organizations in 40 states in a host of activities needed for a national program to sequester CO2.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Texas; Memorandum of agreement between Texas Council on Environmental Quality and the North Central Texas Council of Governments providing emissions offsets to Dallas Fort Worth International airport
Abstract: On 10/29/2004, the EPA published a direct final rule approving incorporation of a Memorandum of Agreement between the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality and the North Central Texas Council of Governments into the Texas SIP. The EPA stated that if it received adverse comment by 11/29/2004, it would publish a timely withdrawal in the Federal Register. Since the EPA subsequently received a timely adverse comment on the direct final rule, the direct final rule is withdrawn as of 12/17/2004. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 includes air pollution control, NO2, ozone, VOC, etc.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News downstream: Shell completes year-long GTL fuel trial...
Abstract: Shell has announced the results of a year-long gas-to-liquids (GTL) fuel trial involving six trucks operating on conventional engines provided by California-based bottled water distributor, Yosemite Waters. GTL fuel reduced all regulated emissions, with a cut in NOx and particulate matter (PM) emissions by 16 and 23%, respectively, during a New York City Bus drive (NYCB) cycle without a particulate filter. The NYCB cycle is a standard set of simulated driving conditions used by researchers to test emissions. With a catalyzed diesel particulate filter, NOx and PM emissions were further reduced, with overall reductions of 20 and 97%, respectively. These trial results provide important data to legislators, commercial users, and the public and will allow them to make better decisions about air quality.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Ambient air pollution: Health hazards to children committee on environmental health
Abstract: Ambient (outdoor) air pollution is now recognized as an important problem, both nationally and worldwide. Our scientific understanding of the spectrum of health effects of air pollution has increased, and numerous studies are finding important health effects from air pollution at levels once considered safe. Children and infants are among the most susceptible to many of the air pollutants. In addition to associations between air pollution and respiratory symptoms, asthma exacerbations, and asthma hospitalizations, recent studies have found links between air pollution and preterm birth, infant mortality, deficits in lung growth, and possibly, development of asthma. This policy statement summarizes the recent literature linking ambient air pollution to adverse health outcomes in children and includes a perspective on the current regulatory process. The statement provides advice to pediatricians on how to integrate issues regarding air quality and health into patient education and children's environmental health advocacy and concludes with recommendations to the government on promotion of effective air-pollution policies to ensure protection of children's health. Copyright © 2004 by the American Academy of Pediatrics.
Author Keywords: Adverse effects; Air pollution; Asthma; Children; Environmental health

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: MTU CFC Solutions orders more DFCs, begins dual-fuel operation
Abstract: MTU CFC Solutions has placed a new order with Fuel-Cell Energy (FCE) in Connecticut, for Direct FuelCell® components for three new sub-Mw molten carbonate fuel cell power plants, for delivery in early 2005. In September 2004, MTU began operation of Europe's first dual-fuel, 250 kwe carbonate fuel cell power plant for Vattenfall/BeWag, a Berlin-based utility. This unit will operate on natural gas, methanol form organic waste/biomass generated from refuse in Berlin, or a mix of both, the first of its kind in Europe. MTU's HotModule® carbonate fuel cell power plant is based on FCE's DFC® technology, utilizing fuel cells built at FCE's manufacturing facility in the US. Meanwhile, RWE Fuel Cells, a stakeholder in MTU CFC Solutions, is working on the installation of a 250 kwe carbonate fuel cell power plant for a municipal wastewater treatment facility in the German city of Ahlen. This system will be the first carbonate fuel cell to reoperate on anaerobic digester gas in Europe.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: FCE, Chevron Energy Solutions sell first DFC1500 in California
Abstract: FuelCell Energy has sold its first 1 Mwe Direct FuelCell power plant in California to Alameda County for the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin. This is FCE's first fuel cell project with Chevron Energy Solutions. FCE will provide Alameda County with the power plant and related operating and maintenance services. Chevron Energy Solutions will act as overall project manager and integrator, providing design, engineering, construction, and installation services to Alameda County. The DFC1500 is expected to provide 90% of baseload power requirements for the Santa Rita Jail. The addition of this 1 Mwe fuel cell power plant to the jail's existing 1.18 Mwe solar power system gives the County the most environmentally sound distributed power system in the county. The system combines the baseload capabilities of the fuel cell plant with the daytime peaking characteristics of photovoltaic. Alameda Country is receiving up to $1.4 million in project funding from the California Public Utilities Commission's Self Generation Incentive Program, and a $1 million grant from the DOD's 2003 Climate Change Fuel Cell Program.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EPA announces west coast diesel initiative ... SCR for nissan truck ... fuel cell system for jail
Abstract: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and a group of agencies have launched a $6 million West coast diesel emissions reduction collaborative initiative. The initiative has been taken in order to reduce the diesel emissions from trucks, ships, locomotives and other diesel sources and to provide solutions and funding to reduce diesel emissions. The initiatives also include: development of a new low-emission diesel truck that will use a urea SCR system to reduce the amount of nitrogen oxide and sale of a 1 MW Direct Fuel Cell (DFC) power plant to Alameda County for the Santa Rita jail in Dublin, California. The goal is to secure $100 million through public and private partnership to address diesel pollution problems in the west.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Catalyst selectivity; Costs; Environmental protection; Industrial trucks; Natural gas; Nitrogen oxides; Particulate emissions; Project management; Retrofitting; Societies and institutions; Torque; Consortium; Diesel emissions; Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); FuelCell Energy Inc. (CO); Nissan Diesel Motor Co. (CO); Private partnerships; Westport Innovations Inc. (CO); Diesel fuels

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of state implementation plans; Indiana; Rules to control particulate matter and carbon monoxide from incinerators
Abstract: On 10/30/2002, and 1/10/2003, Indiana submitted a plan to EPA, which contained revised and updated rules to control emissions of particulate matter and CO from incinerators and other industrial categories, e.g., petroleum refineries, ferrous smelters, and refuse incinerators. The rule changes accomplish several objectives, i.e., re-adaptation of useful elements of regulations, which were scheduled to expire because of "sunset requirements" under the Indiana Code; incorporation by reference a number of applicable EPA rules affecting certain types of incineration units and clarify, which limits pertain to other types of units; and Indiana's elimination of references to language which is outdated and unclear. EPA is approving this State plan revision. This rule is effective 1/31/2005, unless EPA receives relevant adverse written comments by 12/30/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: Cathay Merchant Group Inc., an affiliate of MPC Bancorp Ltd.,..
Abstract: Cathay Merchant Group Inc, an affiliate of MFC Bancorp Ltd, Hong Kong, is developing its first wind energy project in China. The Twin Dragon Wind Farm is planned as a 160 Mw project in Hebei Province, a site chosen by Cathay for its "world-class wind resources" in a large gap facing the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The first phase of development will have capacity of 100 Mw (50-70 wind turbines) at an expected cost of $125 million. The projected annual output from this phase is 400,000 Mw-hr and Cathay expects the project also will be eligible to sell emission credits for the reduction of 300,000 ton/yr of CO2.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plan; Wisconsin
Abstract: The EPA is approving revisions to Wisconsin's SIP regarding the control of NOx emissions submitted on 5/25/2004. On 8/29/2003, the EPA published a final rulemaking approving the omission averaging program fur existing sources subject to the state's rule limiting NOx emissions in southeast Wisconsin. The SIP revisions modify language to clarify which sources are eligible to participate in the NOx emission averaging program. The revision also creates a separate categorical emission limit for new combustion turbines burning biologically derived gaseous fuels. This direct final rule is effective on 1/10/2005 unless EPA receives adverse written comments by 12/10/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: $6 million diesel emission reduction effort
Abstract: A $6 million effort to reduce diesel emissions from trucks, ships, locomotives and other diesel sources along the West Coast of the US was initiated by EPA, joined with a consortium of federal state and local government agencies, non-profits, and industry. Organized as the West Coast Diesel Emissions Reductions Collaborative, more than 400 interests are working together to find voluntary solutions, incentives and shared approaches to reducing diesel pollution in California, Oregon, Washington, and Alaska sooner than federally mandated deadlines. Interests from British Columbia and Mexico have also joined this effort.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Asia'a growing position
Abstract: Switzerland-based Holcim's significant business growth in Asia is discussed. Holcim turned its attention to Asia Pacific's potential in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The most significant expansion occurred in the 1990s, when a combination of industry rationalization worldwide and the Asian financial crisis gave rise to a number of acquisition opportunities for the company. Manufacturing maintenance has been a key area of concentration for the assets acquired by Holcim. The upgrading of IT systems through the regional IT service center based in Bangkok has also played an important role in adding to efficiencies in all areas of the new companies.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Database systems; Economic and social effects; Environmental impact; Geographical regions; Health care; Industrial economics; Information technology; Investments; Mergers and acquisitions; Occupational risks; Personnel training; Preventive maintenance; Project management; Strategic planning; Sustainable development; Dust emission reduction; Holcim (CO); National Cement Industry (CO); Technical training; Cement industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: Fuels & fueling: Biodiesel terminal opens in Colorado
Abstract: On 9/9/2004, Blue Sun Biodiesel and Alta Fuels announced the first high-volume commercial biodiesel terminal in the US, to be opened and operational in the fall. The state-of-the-art sequential blending facility, located in Alamosa, CO, will provide easy access to Blue Sun B20 for fuel distributors and their consumers throughout southern Colorado and New Mexico. Blue Sun B20, which is a renewable fuel produced from virgin vegetable oil biodiesel, proprietary fuel additives, and diesel fuel in a 20:80 biodiesel/diesel ratio, will be loaded onto rail cars and transported throughout the western US. The blend offers advantages over petroleum diesel by increasing cetane, horsepower, and fuel mileage, while reducing emissions of particulates, greenhouse gases, carcinogens, SO2, CO, and hydrocarbons.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: 2003 luzenac Sustainable Development report [Rapport 2003 du Groupe Luzenac sur le Développement Durable]
Abstract: Luzenac, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Rio Tinto, a world leader in the finding, mining and processing of mineral resources, is the world's largest talc producer. Every year, they produce and sell in excess of 1.4 million tonnes of talc from 11 mines and 20 processing plants in Europe, North America and Asia-Pacific. The concrete actions taken in 2003 in terms of sustainable development included offsetting greenhouse gas emissions, taking a structured approach to community relations, promoting biodiversity, and an increased contribution of the human resources function to Sustainable Development.
Index Keywords: Biodiversity; Gas emissions; Management; Mineral resources; Mining; Sales; Talc; Community relations; Greenhouse gases; Processing plants; Sustainable development

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Report highlights advantages of aluminium in cars
Abstract: Various advantages of use of aluminum in cars are discussed. It has been shown that aluminum products in the automotive sector help reduce greenhouse gas emissions from transport, and every kiliogram of aluminum that replaces traditional higher density materials in a vehicle saves the equivalent of 20kg of carbon dioxide emissions. The aluminum industry is working closely with the automobile manufacturers to enable the easier dismantling of aluminum components from cars to improve recovery of aluminum. It has been also estimated that the substitution of aluminum for higher density traditional materials saves 2.5t of CO2 equivalents (878 liters of fuel) over the lifetime of todays's average North American passenger car.
Index Keywords: Automobiles; Automotive industry; Carbon dioxide; Fuel consumption; Motor transportation; Scrap metal; Smelting; Societies and institutions; Standards; Trucks; Australian Aluminum Council (AAC); Fuel efficiencies; Greenhouses gases (GHG); International Organization for Standardization (ISO); Recycling rates; Aluminum

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: IISI - 38th Annual Conference
Abstract: The 38th International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) Annual Conference, which was held in Istanbul, Turkey, discussed the buoyant state of the steel market. Five major Chinese steel companies became the members of IISI at the meeting, the first to do so from this region which dominates world output. The focus on coal and ore was the result of an interim report by the IISI Committee on raw materials. A report on the Turkish steel industry and the impact of the Kyoto Protocol and the EU Emission Trading Scheme on the steel industry was presented in the opening session.
Index Keywords: International trade; Investments; Raw materials; Reengineering; Technical presentations; Chinese steel companies; International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI); Steel production; Iron and steel industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of plan revisions; Indiana
Abstract: EPA is approving Indiana's 2/10/2004 and 4/12/2004 submittal of a revision to its existing emission reporting rule to be consistent with the emission statement program requirements for stationary sources in the CAAA. This requirement applies to all ozone nonattainment areas, regardless of classification. This rule requires sources to submit emission statement data to the Indiana Department of Environmental Management on an annual basis. This emission data collected can help the Department develop a complete and accurate emission inventory for air quality planning purposes at the State, and also meet emission reporting requirements to EPA. On 4/12/2004, Indiana submitted its final rule as published in the Indiana Register. Indiana held a public hearing on the submittal on 12/3/2004. The rationale for the approval and other information are provided in this rulemaking action. This direct final rule is effective on 12/28/2004, without further notice, unless the EPA receives adverse written comment by 11/29/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Texas; Memorandum of agreement between Texas Council on Environmental Quality and the North Central Texas Council of Governments providing emission offsets to Dallas Forth Worth International Airport
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action approving a SIP revision submitted by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) on 2/23/2004. This revision concerns the Dallas/Fort Worth ozone nonattainment area. EPA is approving incorporation of a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) between the TCEQ and the North Central Texas Council of Governments (NCTCOG) into the SIP. This MOA commits the NCTCOG to provide the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport with emissions offsets in the amount of 0.18 ton/day of NOx and 0.04 ton/day of VOC in 2007 and to adjust the modeled 2015 on-road emission estimates to reflect an increase of 1.17 ton/day of NOx and 0.26 ton/day of VOC, which must be accommodated in future transportation conformity determinations. This rule is effective 12/28/2004, without further notice, unless the EPA receives adverse written comment by 11/29/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: California state motor vehicle pollution control standards; Waiver of federal preemption for off-cycle emission test requirements; Notice of decision
Abstract: EPA, pursuant to section 209(b) of the Clean Air Act (Act), 42 USC 7543 (b), is granting California its request for a waiver of federal preemption for its regulations controlling emissions from off-cycle aggressive driving and air-conditioning usage for motor vehicles under 8501 lb gross vehicle weight rating. CARB requested that EPA grant California a waiver of federal preemption for its regulations which incorporate EPA's two supplemental federal test procedures and associated certification standards.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Landfill methane fuels green energy program
Abstract: The Kieffer Landfill (California) has a 15-year purchase agreement with the Sacramento Municipal Utility District (SMUD) to have its methane used in the SMUD Greenery program. The gas-to-energy plant pulls methane via 150 wells drilled into the Kieffer landfill. The gases are used to run three Caterpillar internal combustion engines that turn generators to produce electricity.
Index Keywords: Electric utilities; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Gas fuels; Global warming; Greenhouse effect; Methane; Power generation; Renewable energy resources; Global warming impact; Green energy; Landfill methane fuels; Man made methane emissions; Power utility; Land fill

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Forum: Fuel-borne catalyst for improved fuel consumption
Abstract: CERULEAN International has an agreement with BASF to cooperate in the further development and commercialization of ENVIROX, a new fuel-borne catalyst with demonstrated benefits of improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. BASF will use their global experience in the fuel and fuel additive markets to introduce the product to fuel marketers in both Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. CERULEAN is a subsidiary of OXONICA focused on commercializing ENVIROX in the fuels market. OXONICA designs functional nanomaterials and was spun out from the University of Oxford in 1999.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry news: E.U. greenhouse gas emissions decline
Abstract: Greenhouse gas emissions from the EU have fallen slightly after 2 yr of increase, taking member nations a step closer to their target of an 8% cut over the next 8 yr. According to the latest estimates compiled by the European Environment Agency, greenhouse gas emissions from the EU's 15 pre-2004 member states dropped by 0.5% between 2001 and 2002. The reasons for the decrease include warmer weather in most EU countries that reduced the use of CO2-producing fossil fuels to heat homes and offices. Other key reasons include lower economic growth in manufacturing industries, a continuing shift from coal to gas, and measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News downstream: Shell unveils Shangahi GTL fuel trail
Abstract: Shell Shanghai and Pudong Bus Transportation Co have jointly launched a road trial of Shell's gas-to-liquids (GTL) fuel in Shanghai. Buses from Pudong Bus will be fueled by a blend of GTL fuel and standard diesel over a 2-mo period on a route through the Pudong New District, Shanghai. The trial will involve 12 buses with standard Euro 1 engines. Eight of these buses will use a mixture of 30% GTL fuel and standard diesel. The remaining will use standard diesel as a comparison. During the trial, the reduction in emissions and improvement in fuel efficiency and noise levels of the GTL-fueled buses will be measured and compared.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Member country focus: ADB backs air quality management plan for Indonesian cities
Abstract: The Asian Development Bank will help develop an air quality management strategy and action plan for Indonesia through a technical assistance grant. The United Nations Environment Programme ranks Jakarta as one of the world's most polluted mega-cities. Levels of lead, NO2, and particulates in air are significantly higher than World Health Organization standards, primarily due to vehicles and industry. The grant, from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Japanese government, will help improve the framework of urban air quality management and strengthen enforcement strategies. Air pollution costs the Indonesian economy at least $400 million every year, which could increase 10-fold by 2010 in the absence of air pollution control. Indonesia's National Development Planning Agency will implement the grant, which will be conducted in two phases over 12 mo to October 2005.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Longmont Revised carbon monoxide maintenance plan
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Colorado. On 4/12/2004, the Governor of Colorado submitted a revised maintenance plan for the Longmont CO maintenance area for the CO NAAQS. The revised maintenance plan contains revised transportation conformity motor vehicle emissions budgets for 2010 through 2014, and for 2015 and beyond. In this action, EPA is approving the Longmont CO revised maintenance plan and the revised transportation conformity motor vehicle emissions budgets. This action is being taken under section 110 of the CAAA. This rule is effective on 11/29/2004, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comment by 11/1/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Interim final determination to stay and/or defer sanctions, Maricopa County Environmental Services Department
Abstract: EPA is making an interim final determination to stay and/or defer imposition of sanctions based on a proposed approval of revisions to the Maricopa County Environmental Services Department (MCESD) portion of the Arizona SIP published in the Federal Register. The revisions concern MCESD Rule 331. List of subjects in 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental regulations, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC. This interim final determination is effective on 9/30/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Nevada; Las Vegas Valley carbon monoxide nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is taking final action under the CAAA to approve SIP revisions submitted by the State of Nevada to provide for attainment of the CO NAAQS in Las Vegas Valley, including an alternate low enhanced vehicle inspection and maintenance program, State and local wintertime gasoline rules, and motor vehicle emissions budgets for transportation conformity. This rule is effective on 10/21/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maryland; Revised major stationary source applicability for reasonably available control technology and permitting and revised offset ratios for the Washington area
Abstract: EPA is approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Maryland, which pertains to changes in Maryland's regulations for new source permitting for major sources of VOC and NOx emissions and regulations requiring RACT on major stationary sources of NOx in the Washington, DC ozone nonattainment area. The revision modifies the currently approved SIP to make changes applicable in the Washington, DC ozone nonattainment area: modify the emissions offset ratio; lower the applicability threshold of the new source review permit program; and lower the applicability threshold of the NOx RACT rule. This final rule is effective on 10/20/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Denver revised carbon monoxide maintenance plan
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Colorado. On 10/15/2003, the Governor of Colorado submitted a revised maintenance plan for the Denver-Boulder metropolitan CO maintenance area for the CO NAAQS. The revised maintenance plan also contained a revised transportation conformity budget for 2013. In this action, EPA is approving the Denver CO revised maintenance plan and revised transportation conformity budget. This action is being taken under section 110 of the CAAA. This rule is effective on 11/15/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Viginia; Update to materials incorporated by reference
Abstract: The EPA is updating the materials submitted by The Commonwealth of Virginia that are incorporated by reference into the SIP. The regulations affected by this update have been previously submitted by the State agency, the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality, and approved by EPA. This update affects the SIP materials that are available for public inspection at the National Archives and Records Administration, the Air and Radiation Docket and Information Center located at EPA Headquarters, Washington, DC, and the Regional Office. Approved Virginia regulations include emission standards for petroleum liquid storage and transfer operations, emission standards for asphalt paving operations, emission standards for mobile sources, etc. This action is effective on 9/8/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New source review; State of Nevada, Clark County Department of Air Quality and Environmental Management
Abstract: The EPA is taking final action to partially approve and partially disapprove revisions to the Clark County portion of the Nevada SIP. These revisions concern rules adopted by the Clark County Board of County Commissioners for issuing permits for new or modified stationary sources in Clark County to comply with the applicable permitting requirements under parts C and D of title I of the CAAA. These provisions of the Clean Air Act are designed to prevent significant deterioration in attainment areas and to attain the NAAQS in nonattainment areas. Submitted rules include ambient air quality standards, gasoline dispensing facilities (Section 52 Offset Program), emission reduction credits, etc. This rule is effective on 10/7/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Colorado Springs revised carbon monoxide maintenance plan and approval of related revisions
Abstract: The EPA is taking direct final action approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Colorado. On 4/12/2004, the Governor of Colorado submitted a revised maintenance plan for the Colorado Springs CO maintenance area for the CO NAAQS. The revised maintenance plan contains a revised transportation conformity budget for the year 2010 and beyond. The Governor submitted revisions to Colorado's Regulation No. 11 "Motor Vehicle Emissions Inspection Program". In this action, EPA is approving the Colorado Springs CO revised maintenance plan, revised transportation conformity budget, and the revisions to Regulation No. 11. This rule is effective on 11/8/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EU 15 Greenhouse gas emissions decline after two years of increases
Abstract: Greenhouse gas emissions from the EU 15 pre-2004 member states dropped by 0.5% between 2001 and 2002. The reasons for the decrease include warmer weather in most EU countries which reduced the use of carbon dioxide producing fossil fuels to heat homes and offices. Slower economic growth in manufacturing industries, which also lowered fossil fuel use, a continuing shift from coal to gas and specific measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions were the other main reasons. Emissions of six greenhouse gases had risen by 0.2% and 1.3% a year in 2000 and 2001 respectively.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Climate change; Environmental protection; Forestry; Fossil fuels; Greenhouse effect; Land fill; Regulatory compliance; Fossil-fuel based power generation; Heat production; Methane emission; Gas emissions; Carbon Dioxide; Emission; Environments; Forestry; Fossil Fuels; Greenhouse Effect; Legislation

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: BP - Seal Sands CATS
Abstract: THE entry from BP's CATS terminal at Seal Sands demonstrate how reducing environmental impact can go hand-in-hand with economic growth. CO2 emissions decreased by 5.7%, attributed to the close attention to fuel gas use and flare purges, and recycling a methane purge. Liquid effluent reduced by 37.8% through an effluent-specific reed bed and a small on-site sewerage treatment plant. For solid waste, a range of waste recycling stations and motivating the troops cut it by 19.9%. Local children come to the iced bed; to spot bird and aquatic insect life, one of many community activities thriving at the terminal. For these efforts, BP is nominated for the ABB Engineering Services Environment Award at the 11th Annual IChemE Awards of 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Minnesota; Sulfur dioxide; United Defense
Abstract: The EPA is approving a revision to Minnesota's SIP for SO2 for the United Defense, LP facility located in Anoka County, MN. This revision replaces the Administrative Order, originally issued to the facility on 5/27/92, with a Title V permit containing non-expiring Title I SIP conditions, issued on 11/25/2002. The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency submitted this SIP revision on 12/19/2002. Non-expiring permit conditions limit the sulfur content in the fuel used, while the Administrative Order set emission limits for SO2. The new boilers are restricted to using either natural gas or No. 2 fuel oil with a maximum of 0.05 wt % sulfur. To demonstrate compliance with these provisions, the facility is required to obtain and maintain written documentation of each shipment of No. 2 fuel oil and diesel oil received for the boilers. This direct final rule is effective on 10/18/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Connecticut; Carbon monoxide maintenance plan updates; Limited maintenance plans
Abstract: EPA approves a SIP revision submitted by the State of Connecticut. This revision establishes limited maintenance plans for the Hartford-New Britain-Middletown, the New Haven-Meriden-Waterbury, and the Connecticut portion of the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island CO attainment areas, and provides the 10-yr update to these three CO maintenance plans. EPA is taking this action under the Clean Air Act. As a result of approving the limited maintenance plan revisions, the three CO attainment areas with maintenance plans will satisfy their obligation to submit sequential second 10-yr maintenance plan, and eliminate the need to prepare regional CO emissions analysis for transportation conformity. This rule is effective on 9/13/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry trends: Ultraclean diesel fuel...
Abstract: O2Diesel Corp's proprietary ethanol-based blend has been certified as an acceptable clean fuel by Nevada and California state government officials. The company claims its fuel reduces vehicle emissions of ozone-forming NOx. Its technology will be used to supply 10,000-20,000 ton to Al-Obayya Corp. Al-Obayya plans to distribute and market O2Diesel's fuel through the Middle East. In the US, the Nevada Division of Environmental Protection officially included O2Diesel on its list of alternative fuels that state, county, and municipal fleets of ≥ 10 vehicles can use instead of conventional gasoline or diesel.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans New Jersey emission statement program
Abstract: The EPA is approving the SIP revisions submitted by the State of New Jersey on 1/23/2003, for the purpose of enhancing an existing Emission Statement Program for stationary sources in New Jersey. The SIP revision consists of amendments to the New Jersey Administrative Code title 7, chapter 27, subchapter 21, Emission Statements. The SIP revision was submitted by New Jersey to satisfy the Clean Air Act requirements for stationary sources to reports annually to the State on their emissions of VOC, NOx, and CO, in order for the State to make this data available to EPA and the public. The rule enhances the reporting requirements of VOC and NOx and expands the reporting requirement based on specified emission thresholds to include CO, SO2, total suspended particulate matter (TSP), PM2.5, PM10, NH3, lead, hazardous air pollutants, and CO2 and CH4. The intended effect is to provide improved information to plan for and attain the air quality standards. This rule will be effective 9/1/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Landfill gas powers food processing firm
Abstract: A cooperative project involving a food and beverage company, a major waste management firm, a regional energy utility, and a Louisiana technology business specializing in emissions reduction projects is creating a system to collect and utilize gas generated from decomposing MSW at the BFI South Shelby Landfill. This project is meaningful as it demonstrates how important community benefits can be achieved through cooperation and investment among companies, utility providers and government organizations.
Index Keywords: Landfill gas; Landfill gas powers; Methane recovery; Biogas; Carbon dioxide; Cost benefit analysis; Food processing; Food products plants; Land fill; Methane; Recycling; Societies and institutions; Waste heat utilization; Waste management

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Stone, Weyerhaeuser settle EPA pollution cases
Abstract: Stone Container and Weyrhaeuser have separately settled an agreement with the Environmental Protection Agency for settling federal and state air pollution violation cases. Stone Container agreed to pay $ 835,000 penalty to resolve alleged violations of the federal Clean Air Act and Virginia's Air Pollution Control Law. Wayerhaeuser has agreed to pay a sum of $ 900,000 penalty and improve air pollution controls at its kraft pulp and paper mill in Johnsonburg. The alleged violations included failing to adequately monitor emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, exceeding regulatory limits of emissions and failing to adopt safegaurds to stop sulfur emissions.
Index Keywords: Particulate matter; Penalty; Stone Container (CO); Wyerhaeuser (CO); Air pollution control; Industrial emissions; Laws and legislation; Nitrogen oxides; Paper and pulp mills; Particulate emissions; Regulatory compliance; Sulfur dioxide; Air pollution; Air Pollution; EPA; Kraft Mills; Nitrogen Oxides; Particulate Emissions; Regulations; Sulfur Dioxide

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California state implementation plan, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the South Coast Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. These revisions were proposed on the Federal Register on 5/21/2004 and concern NOx and SOx emissions from facilities emitting ≥ 4 ton/yr of NOx and/or SOx in the year 1990 or any subsequent year. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 8/25/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Transportation conformity rule amendments for the new 8-hour ozone and PM2.5 national ambient air quality standards and miscellaneous revisions for existing areas; Transportation conformity rule amendments; Response to court decision and additional rule changes; Correction to the preamble
Abstract: EPA issued a final rule on 7/1/2004 that amended the transportation conformity rule to include criteria and procedures for the new 8-hr ozone and fine particulate matter (PM2.5) NAAQS. The final rule also addressed a 3/2/99 ruling by the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The preamble to the final rule contains two errors. This notice is intended to correct these errors. All other preamble and regulatory text printed in the 7/1/2004 final rule is correct. The DOT is EPA's federal partner in implementing the transportation conformity regulations. Effective date is 8/2/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: SO2 emissions
Abstract: The EU Environment Council has agreed to reduce ships' SO2 emissions by over 500,000 ton/yr from 2007. Marine fuel currently has maximum sulfur content of 5%; this will reduce to 1.5% for all vessels in the Baltic and North Seas and English Channel and for ferries on regular services.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Technology: BASF links to China
Abstract: BASF and Chinese Research Academy for Environmental Science (Craes) have signed a joint agreement to build an engine test laboratory in Beijing, China. The laboratory will house a dynamometer, which will test the quality of Chinese gasoline and look at ways to improve the quality of automotive fuel and make reductions in exhaust gas emissions. One of the key projects for Craes, which reports directly to the Chinese state environmental protection administration, is to reduce air pollution caused by automotive vehicles.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Partial withdrawal of direct final rule revising the California and Nevada state implementation plans, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District and Clark County Department of Air Quality Management
Abstract: On 5/20/2004, EPA published a direct final approval of a revision to the Nevada SIP, concerning Clark County Department of Air Quality Management Section 11, Ambient Air Quality Standards. On its own initiative, EPA is withdrawing the 5/20/2004 direct final rule with respect to section 11 to avoid confusion with a subsequent action in which EPA proposed approval of Section 11 along with other Clark County air pollution control rules relating to the local New Source Review program. The other rule, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District Rule 34, approved in the 5/20/204 direct final action, is not affected by this withdrawal and is incorporated into the SIP as of 7/19/2004, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 6/21/2004, as set forth in the 5/20/2004 direct final rule.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New Jersey 1-hour ozone control programs
Abstract: EPA approves a request from New Jersey to revise its SIP to incorporate revisions to Subchapter 16 "Control and Prohibition of Air Pollution by VOC". These revisions relate to the control of VOC compounds from mobile equipment repair and refinishing operations, solvent cleaning operations, and refueling of motor vehicles at gasoline service stations. The intended effect is to reduce the emissions of VOC and thereby reduce ozone concentrations in the lower atmosphere. This adoption was published in the New Jersey Register on 6/2/2003 and became effective on 6/29/2003. New Jersey amended Subchapter 16 to include revisions to three control programs: solvent cleaning operations, mobile equipment repair and refinishing operations, and gasoline transfer operations. The Subchapter 16 amendments are applicable to the entire State of New Jersey. This rule is effective 8/2/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Aerosol story gets new angle
Abstract: The role played by aromatic acids in the formation of hazardous nanometre-sized particles in the atmosphere is discussed. The aromatic acids are found to enhance the nucleation of sulfuric acid resulting in the formation of an unusually stable aromatic acid-sulfuric acid complex which encourages particle formation. It is suggested that regulatory controls in both automobile volatile organic compounds (VOC) and power plant SO2 emissions need to be considered to reduce the aerosol effects on human health, global climate, and local weather. The improvement in understanding of the formation and transformation of aerosols in the atmosphere can help in reducing the effects of atmospheric particulate matter at the legislative level.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Aromatic hydrocarbons; Carboxylic acids; Fossil fuels; Nucleation; Particulate emissions; Power plants; Sulfur dioxide; Sulfuric acid; Volatile organic compounds; Aromatic acid-sulfuric acid complex; Department of Atmospheric Sciences; Nanometre-sized particles; Photochemical degradation; Atmospheric aerosols

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News briefs: Diesel rule's ramifications
Abstract: The Clean Air Nonroad Diesel Rule was introduced to reduce emission levels from construction-, agricultural-, and industrial-powered diesel equipment by > 90% within 10 yr and eradicate 99% of sulfur from diesel fuel by 2010. EPA states that the rule is part of the Clean Diesel Programs, a group of regulations that is expected to lead to the most significant change to the air since the introduction of catalytic converters to cars in the 1970s. The agency insists that the benefits far outweigh its costs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Johnson Matthey CRT re-verified by GARB... tool kit for diesel retrofits... more orders for cummins westport
Abstract: The Johnson Matthey's Continuously Regenerating Technology (CRT) particulate filter is reverified as a level-3 diesel emission control device by the California Air Resources Board (CARB). The Diesel technology Forum has launched a Clean Diesel Retrofit Tool Kit in order to expand diesel retrofits as a cost-effective emissions reduction technology. The tool kit is a comprehensive guide for state transportation officials and metropolitan planning organisations (MPOs) to implement diesel retrofit programs. Hydrogenics Corp. and Chevron Texaco Technology Ventures LLS is developing a hydrogen energy station for power generation and transportation fuel applications. An engine order of 150 C gas plus engines foe buses is received by Cummins WestPort.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Diesel fuels; Electric generators; Fuel cells; Gas engines; Hydrogen; Military applications; Motor transportation; Natural gas; Particles (particulate matter); Particulate emissions; Retrofitting; Alternative Fuel Systems (CO); Clean Diesel Technologies Inc (CO); Cummins Westport (CO); Hydrogenics Corp (CO); Johnson Matthey (CO); Quantum Fuel System Technologies Worldwide (CO); Diesel engines

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maryland; Control of volatile organic compound emissions from portable fuel containers
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Maryland SIP. The revisions pertain to new VOC emission standards for portable fuel containers. EPA is approving these revisions in accordance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 8/30/2004 without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 7/29/2004. Implementation of this rule will result in statewide emission reductions, and will help the ozone non-attainment areas in the state attain the one-hr ozone standard.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Control of emissions of air pollution from nonroad diesel engines and fuel; final rule
Abstract: EPA is adopting new emission standards for nonroad diesel engines and sulfur reductions in nonroad diesel fuel that will reduce harmful emissions and will directly help States and local areas recently designated as 8-hr ozone non-attainment areas to improve their air quality. This comprehensive national program regulates nonroad diesel engines and diesel fuel as a system. New engine standards will begin to take effect in the 2008 model year, phasing in over a number of years. These standards are based on the use of advanced exhaust emission control devices. EPA estimate particulate matter reductions of 95%, NOx reductions of 90%, and the virtual elimination of SOx from nonroad engines meeting the new standards. The rule also includes provisions to facilitate the transition to the new engine and fuel standards and to encourage the early introduction of clean technologies and clean nonroad diesel fuel. EPA also developed provisions for both the engine and fuel programs designed to address small business considerations. The requirements in this rule will result in substantial benefits to public health and welfare through significant reductions in emissions of NOx and particulate matter, as well as non-methane hydrocarbons, CO, SOx, and air toxics. The total benefits of this rule will be ≈ $80 billion/yr by 2030. Costs for both the engine and fuel requirements will be many times less, at ≈ $2 billion/yr. This final rule is effective on 8/30/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Delaware; update to materials incorporated by reference
Abstract: EPA is updating the materials submitted by Delaware that are incorporated by reference into the SIP. The regulations affected by this update have been previously submitted by the State agency and approved by EPA. This update affects the SIP materials that are available for public inspection at the Office of the Federal Register, the Air and Radiation Docket and Information Center located at EPA Headquarters in Washington, DC, and the Regional Office. In this action, EPA make corrections to the charts listed in §52.420(c), e.g., Regulation 5 (Particulate Emissions from Industrial Process Operations), Section 5 (Restrictions on Petroleum Refining Operations), wherein the text in the "Comments" column is removed; Regulation 11 (CO emissions from Indusrial Process Operations - New Castle County), wherein the text in the "Comments" column is removed from the Section 1 entry (General Provisions) to the Section 2 entry (Restrictions on Petroleum Refining Operations; and Regulation 40 (National Low Emission Vehicle Program), in which EPA approved thsi regulation as a revision to the Delaware SIP on 12/28/99 (64 FR 72564), and therefore added an entry to the table in §52.420(c). This action is effective on 6/21/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Nevada-Las Vegas Valley PM-10 nonattainment area; Serious area plan for attainment of the annual and 24-hour PM-10 standards
Abstract: EPA is approving the serious area particulate matter (PM-10) plan for the Las Vegas Planning Area that addresses attainment of the annual and 24-hr PM-10 NAAQS and includes motor vehicle emissions budgets for transportation conformity. EPA is also granting Nevada's request to extend the Clean Air Act deadline for attaining the 24-hr PM-10 standard in the Las Vegas area from 2001 to 2006. EPA is approving into the SIP fugitive dust rules adopted by Clark County. This rule is effective on 7/9/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Government developments: The Canadian government, seeking...
Abstract: The Canadian government, seeking to cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and reduce fuel costs, is sponsoring a $1.4 million pilot program in Ontario, Alberta, and British Columbia to encourage the use of on-road vehicles fueled by CNG. Natural Resources Canada (NRC) is funding the project, which the Canadian Natural Gas Vehicles Alliance will implement. The initiative will allow NRC to explore the opportunities and obstacles inherent in CNG vehicle use in the commercial fleet sector, especially in urban areas. It will also provide data for developing a successful long-term program. The project will also study issues such as a made-in-Canada emissions verification system and the regulation of modified CNG vehicles, which NRC will produce 21% fewer GHG emissions than those fueled by conventional gasoline.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Rulemaking on Section 126 petitions from New York and Connecticut regarding sources in Michigan; Revision of definition of applicable requirement for Title V operating permit programs
Abstract: EPA is revising one element of a final rule published on 1/18/2000, regarding petitions filed by four Northeastern States under section 126 of the CAAA. The petitions seek to mitigate interstate transport of NOx, one of the main precursors of ground-level ozone pollution. The final rule partially approved the four petitions under the 1-hr ozone NAAQS, thereby requiring certain types of sources, e.g., industrial boilers and turbines from electric generating units, located in 12 States and the District of Columbia to reduce their NOx emissions. This rule is effective 7/6/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industrial news: US-Mexico border gets air pollution study
Abstract: The Border Ozone Reduction and Air Quality Improvement Programme has selected Alberto Mendoza of the Center for Environmental Quality at the Instituto Technologico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey to carry out a comprehensive study to address the need to reduce air pollution in the international border region between Mexicali and the Imperial Valley. The study will examine air pollutants in the region without regard to geographic boundaries. The Programme was established in late 2002 to contribute to binational air quality improvement policies by awarding a series of applied research grants for projects that will reduce ozone and air toxins in the international border region.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Storage preferred to incineration
Abstract: The Western Australian government is due to receive the recommendations of a committee looking into the treatment of the state's hazardous and industrial waste. This feature looks at the committe's process and advice, as well as a congeneration plant receiving carbon credits, a solar drying technology, a gold mining company receiving an EPA compliance order, treating high level arsenic waste, and polishing hard drives in an environmentally friendly way. Having considered the public submissions, the Core Consultative Committees (3C's) preferred position is that hazardous waste landfilling and thermal treatment of hazardous wastes by methods defined as incineration for regulatory purposes under the European Union's Incineration Directive.
Index Keywords: Arsenic; Carbon; Cogeneration plants; Gas emissions; Gold mines; Hazardous materials; Heat treatment; Land fill; Land use; Mining; Waste incineration; Hazardous waste management; Thermal treatments; Waste reduction; Waste treatment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fuels & fueling: Industry news: First shipment of bioethanol hits the road
Abstract: In April 2004, a milestone in industrial biotechnology was achieved with the first commercial shipment of bioethanol. Unlike conventional ethanol, bioethanol is made from cellulosic biomass, such as wheat straw, sugar-cane bagasse, and corn stovers and stalks left over after harvesting. This green alternative fuel, compatible with current automobile engines, could significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Using this technology, raw materials such as wood-product manufacturing residues, municipal solid waste and garden waste could supply > 500 million dry ton of biomass, enough to make > 50 billion gal of ethanol, which is ∼ 25% of current US gasoline consumption.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, El Dorado County Air Pollution Control District, Feather River Air Quality Management District, Kern County Air Pollution Control District, Sacramento Metropolitan Air Quality Management District, San Bernardino County Air Pollution Control District, Santa Barbara County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the El Dorado County Air Pollution Control District, Feather River Air Quality Management District, Kern County Air Pollution Control District, Sacramento Metropolitan Air Quality Management District, San Bernardino County Air Pollution Control District, Santa Barbara county Air Pollution Control District, and Yolo-Solano Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. Under authority of the CAAA, EPA is approving local rules that address emission statements. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and SOx. This rule is effective on 7/26/2004, without further notice, unless the EPA receives adverse written comment by 6/25/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Missouri update to materials incorporated by reference
Abstract: EPA is updating the materials submitted by Missouri that are incorporated by reference into the SIP. The regulations affected by this update have been previously submitted by the state agency and approved by EPA. This update affects the SIP materials that are available for public inspection at the Office of the Federal Register, Office of Air and Radiation Docket and Information Center, and the Regional Office. Titles include Maximum Allowable Emission of Particulate Matter from Fuel Burning Equipment used for Indirect Heating Incinerators, Liquefied Cutback Asphalt Paving Restricted, Control of Petroleum Liquid Storage, Loading, and Transfer, Control of Gasoline Reid Vapor Pressure, Auto Exhaust Emission Controls, etc. This action is effective 5/24/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revision to the California State Implementation Plan, Bay Area Air Quality Management District, Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District, and Ventura County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Bay Area Air Quality Management District Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control district and Ventura County Air Pollution Control District portions of the California SIP. The revisions concern the emission of VOC from episodic releases from relief devices (at petroleum refineries and chemical plants), the emission of VOC from the transfer of gasoline into storage containers at bulk terminals, and the storage and transfer of gasoline at dispensing facilities. EPA is approving local rules that regulate these emission sources under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 7/23/2004, without further notice, unless the EPA receives adverse written comment by 6/23/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Pennsylvania; The 2005 ROP plan for the Pennsylvania Portion of the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Trenton severe area severe 1-hour ozone nonattainment area
Abstract: EPA is approving SIP revisions submitted by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, which amend the state's rate-of-progress (ROP) plan for 2005 for its portion of the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Trenton severe 1-hr ozone nonattainment area (Philadelphia area). These revisions update the plan's emission inventories and motor vehicle emissions budgets to reflect the use of MOBILE6 while continuing to satisfy the ROP requirement for 2005. The revisions also amend the contingency measures related to the 205 ROP plan. These SIP revisions are being approved in accordance with the CAAA. List of subjects in 40 CFR Part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, NO2, ozone, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, and VOC. This final rule is effective on 6/21/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California and Nevada State Implementation Plans, Ventura County air pollution control district and Clark County Department of Air Quality Management
Abstract: EPA is taking direct final action to approve revisions to the Ventura County Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP and the Clark County Department of Air Quality Management (CCDAQM) portion of the Nevada SIP. Under authority of the CAAA, EPA is approving local rules that address Acid Deposition and the NAAQS. Section 110(a) of the CAAA requires states to submit regulations that control VOC, oxides of nitrogen, particulate matter, SO2, and other air pollutants that harm human health and the environment. CCDAQM Section 11 lists the NAAQS and the State Ambient Air Quality Standards. Section 11 has been revised to include the new 8-hr ozone standard and the PM2.5 standard.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP, which were proposed in the Federal Register on 2/12/2004, and concern NOx emissions from boilers, steam generators, and process heaters; stationary internal combustion engines; and stationary gas turbines. The local rules that regulate these emission sources are being approved under the CAAA. This rule is effective on 6/17/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan; San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is finalizing approval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District (SJVUAPCD) portion of the California SIP. In the Federal Register on 2/13/2003, EPA proposed approval of revised SJVUAPCD Rules 2020 (permit exemptions) and 2201 (New Source Review for stationary sources). The demonstration supports the limited use of pre-baseline Emission Reduction Credits as consistent with attainment of the NAAQS for PM-10. EPA agrees that a similar demonstration must be included in the area's ozone plan to account for pre-baseline emission reduction credits and ensure that the plan generates sufficient credible emission reductions to satisfy reasonable progress and compliance demonstration requirements for extreme ozone nonattainment areas. This rule is effective on 6/16/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Additive advantages
Abstract: The role of Grace Construction Products (GCP), a leading supplier of chemical additives to the Spanish cement industry is discussed. It was stated that GPC has the experience, resources and ability to reduce cement manufacturing costs and increase profitability for cement producers. It is found that when cement is produced with some level of clinker substitution it can reduce emissions of CO2 per ton of cement. The Grace S.A. is the largest Grace plant in Europe and second largest worldwide, which services mainly the Spanish and Portuguese markets. It is estimated that in the last five years, production at Grace S.A has increased by almost 100% due to higher utilization in the region of quality improving cement additives.
Index Keywords: Blending; Carbon dioxide; Cement additives; Costs; Limestone; Research and development management; Standards; AENOR quality; Clinker substitution; Grace Construction Products (GCP); Grinding aids; Cement industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Two FCE units for Santa Barbara wastewater site
Abstract: FuelCell Energy (FCE) and Alliance Power in Colorado will supply two 250 kwe molten carbonate direct FuelCell® power plants to Santa Barbara, CA, expected to be delivered and operational by the end of 2004. The systems will supply 500 kwe of renewable electric power and heat to the city's El Estero wastewater treatment plant, using methane gas from the anaerobic digesters as fuel. FCE has sited other DFC power plants at wastewater treatment facilities in the US and Japan, including its first 1 Mwe DFC1500 in King County, WA.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Final rule to implement the 8-hour ozone national ambient air quality standard - Phase 1
Abstract: EPA is taking final action on key elements of the program to implement the 8-hr ozone NAAQS. This final rule addresses the following topics: classifications for the 8-hr NAAQS; revocation of the 1-hr NAAQS (i.e., when the 1-hr NAAQS will no longer apply); how anti-backsliding principles will ensure continued progress toward attainment of the 8-hr ozone NAAQS; attainment dates; and the timing emissions reductions needed for attainment. EPA is issuing this rule so that States and Tribes will know how the agency plan to classify areas and transition from implementation of the 1-hr NAAQS to implementation of the 8-hr NAAQS. This rule is effective on 6/15/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EU backs carbon credits allowance
Abstract: The European Union (EU) has allowed European chemical industry for carbon credits from developing countries to be used in its emissions trading program which is will start in January 2005. The European Parliament has supported new legislation enabling European companies participating in emissions trading to count credits from emission reduction projects around the world. The legislation should now be formally approved by the Council of Ministers representing EU member states. But, the UK Chemical Industries Association has criticized the EU for proposals to give individual member states the right to limit the number of credits available to individual companies from outside Europe.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Costs; Industrial economics; Industrial emissions; Laws and legislation; Regulatory compliance; Technical presentations; Carbon credits; Chemical industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans, finding of attainment, and designation of areas for air quality planning purposes; 1-hour ozone standard, East Kern County, CA
Abstract: EPA finds that East Kern County, California, has attained the 1-hr ozone NAAQS. EPA approves the East Kern County 1-hr ozone maintenance plan and motor vehicle emissions budgets as revisions to the East Kern County portion of the California SIP. Finally, EPA is redesignates the East Kern County area to attainment for the 1-hr ozone NAAQS. This direct final rule is effective 6/21/2004, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse comments by 5/24/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Conditional approval and promulgation of implementation plans: Michigan: Oxides of nitrogen rules
Abstract: EPA is conditionally approving a SIP revision submitted by the State of Michigan on 4/3/2003. The submittal made by the Michigan Department of Environmental Quality (MDEQ) responds to the EPA's regulation entitled "Finding of Significant Contribution and Rulemaking for Certain States in the Ozone Transport Assessment Group Region for Purposes of Reducing Regional Transport of Ozone" otherwise known as the "NOx SIP Call". The rules submitted by MDEQ establish a NOx emissions allowance trading program for large electric generating and industrial units, and require reductions from large electric generating and industrial units and cement kilns, starting in 2004. EPA is conditionally approving Michigan's Oxides of Nitrogen Budget trading Program because it generally meets the requirements of the Phase I NOx SIP Call designed to significantly reduce ozone in Michigan and ozone transport in the eastern US. This rule is effective on 5/3/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maryland; revisions to the 2005 ROP plan for the Cecil County portion of the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Trenton 1-hour ozone nonattainment area to reflect the use of MOBILE6
Abstract: EPA approves SIP revisions submitted by the State of Maryland, amending the 2005 rate-of-progress (ROP) plan in the Maryland SIP for the Cecil County portion of the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Trenton nonattainment severe 1-hr ozone nonattainment area. The intent of these revisions is to update the Cecil County 2005 ROP plan's mobile emissions inventories and motor vehicle emissions budgets to reflect the use of mobile6 and to amend the contingency measures associated with that plan. This rule is effective on 6/1/2004, without further notice, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 5/17/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of Air Quality Implementation Plans; North Dakota; State Implementation Plan corrections
Abstract: When EPA approved revisions to the North Dakota SIP on 10/8/96, it inadvertently incorporated by reference some revisions to the North Dakota Century Code statute pertaining to an asbestos law. When EPA approved revisions to the North Dakota SIP on 8/27/98, it inadvertently failed to include a subsection of one of the submitted North Dakota Air Pollution Control Rules. The agency is correcting these errors with this document. List of subjects inf 40 CFR part 52 include environmental protection, air pollution control, CO, incorporation by reference, intergovernmental relations, lead, nitrogen dioxide, ozone, particulate matter, reporting and recordkeeping requirements, sulfur oxides, and VOC. This rule is effective on 5/3/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Strategic assault needed on CO2
Abstract: The need to make a strategic assault on CO2, the worst of the greenhouse gases, was the main topic of discussion in the Eviro 04 Conference held in Sydney in March 2004. The sustainable energy industry's role in reducing greenhouse gases and in providing clean, reliable and affordable energy were also discussed. The coal industry is also investigating clean goal technologies like geosequestration. The Australian Government's Mandatory Renewable Energy Target (MRET) policy is working towards a clean energy future by utilizing proven technologies and also delivers many benefits.
Index Keywords: Coal industry; Cost effectiveness; Energy management; Energy utilization; Environmental protection; Greenhouse effect; Renewable energy resources; Sustainable development; Business Council for Sustainable Energy (BCSE); Geosequestration; Greenhouse gases; Carbon dioxide

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: County Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County Joint Water Pollution Control Plant
Abstract: The Joint Water Pollution Control Plant (JWPCP) serves as the central biosolids processing facility for the County Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County's 500-mgd Joint Outfall System. The Districts use a diversified system for biosolids disposal that includes land application, composting and injection to a cement kiln to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions. An energy-self-sufficient facility, JWPCP, uses digester gas in a combined-cycle power plant to produce about 22 MW of power. Each of the facility's digester-gas-fired turbines is equipped with an automatic system that controls the injection of water into the turbine's combustion chamber. The control system meets the emission limits even when the digester gas is supplemented with natural gas.
Index Keywords: Combined cycle power plants; Gas emissions; Kilns; Nitrogen oxides; Sanitation; Water treatment plants; Biosolids; County Sanitation Districts; Joint Outfall System; Joint Water Pollution Control Plant (CO); Water pollution control

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The City Delta project - Assessing urban air pollutant effects
Abstract: The City Delta project commenced in early 2002 as part of the Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) program. CAFE was designed to develop relationships between regional scale air quality levels and the levels found in cities using state-of-the-art models. These relationships will be incorporated into RAINS, the Integrated Assessment Model being used in the CAFE program to examine various emission reduction scenarios as input to policy development. Charts for London, Milan and Paris were assessed to determine the relationship between urban scale and regional scale ozone response to NOx emission reductions. In all three cities, fine scale models showed significant increases in the population weighted levels of AOT30 with reduction in NOx levels beyond the Base Case in 2010. This was expected given that the reduction in NOx removed the NO that titrated the ozone on the city. Hence, ozone levels were not reduced as much over the city as in the Base Case, so population exposure to ozone rose. This has important implications for any cost-benefit assessment based on human population exposure: although further NOx control (beyond that already legislated) may reduce regional scale ozone, it would increase population exposure in cities, implying negative human health benefits.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Zero-emission fuel cell buses for 10 European cities
Abstract: The introduction of zero-emission fuel cell buses in 10 European cities is discussed. Three first generation hydrogen fuel-cell buses vehicles are being trialled as part of a pioneering two-year European financed Clean Urban Transport for Europe (CUTE) project to reduce air pollution and noise.
