The buses run on hydrogen gas, contained in six cylinders on the bus roof. During the trial the fuel cell buses will be subjected to rigorous ecological, technical and economic analysis, and result will be compared with conventional buses. London was chosen to trial the hydrogen fuel cell buses, specially developed by Daimler Chrysler.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Buses; Environmental protection; Hydrogen; Natural gas; Noise pollution; Particulate emissions; Public policy; Compressed gases; Daimler Chrysler (CO); Fuel cell buses; Infrastructure; Fuel cells

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Adequacy status of the anchorage Alaska carbon monoxide maintenance plan for transportation conformity purposes
Abstract: EPA notifies the public that the motor vehicle emissions budgets in the Anchorage, AK, Serious CO Maintenance Plan, submitted by the Governor on 2/18/2004, are adequate for conformity purposes. On 3/2/99, the D.C. Circuit Court ruled that submitted SIP could not be used for conformity determinations until EPA has affirmatively found them adequate. Thus, the Municipality of Anchorage, AK, Department of Transportation & Public Facilities, and the DOT are required to use the motor vehicle emissions budgets in this submitted maintenance plan for future transportation conformity determinations. This finding is effective 5/1/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick Takes: Amvest Osage Inc., a unit of Amvest Corp...
Abstract: Amvest Osage Inc, a unit of Amvest Corp, Charlottesville, VA, has increased coalbed methane (CBM) production to 7.5 million cu ft/day from 83 wells in Osage County, OK, and is continuing CBM and conventional oil and gas development on 370,000 acres on the Osage Reservation. The company will drill 75 wells/yr for several years in Osage lands and will try horizontal drilling this spring 2004 in selected coal seams. Amvest's rights extend to all coal seams and carbonaceous shales. Amvest mainly targets the Dawson, Weir-Pittsburg, and Rowe coals and secondarily the Iron Post, Crowburg, and Bluejacket coals, all of Pennsylvania age. Deepest drilling depths are 2400-2500 ft. In the fiscal ended 7/31/2002. Amvest invested > $21 million, acquiring Delaware-incorporated TEC Resources LLC, drilling 33 wells, and installing gas and water gathering systems. It had drilled 136 wells by late 2003. The former TEC properties still produce 2-2.5 million cu ft/day.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Five U.S. Power Companies Adopt WWF Energy Switch Program
Abstract: Five electric power companies have become the first in the US to support a mandatory cap on carbon dioxide emissions through adoption of program program proposed by World Wildlife Federation (WWF). The companies named Austin Energy, Burlington Electric Department, FPL Group, Sacramento Municipal Utility District and Waverly Light and Power, have agreed to participate in the CO 2 reduction program. Under the commitments to WWF, the renewable energy sources may include solar, wind, sustainably harvested biomass etc. The WWF powerswitch challenge is a blueprint for power companies to support binding limits on national CO2 emissions.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Carbon dioxide; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Gas emissions; Land fill; Optimization; Strategic planning; Wind; Austin Energy (CO); Burlington Electric Department (CO); FPL Group (CO); Sacramento Municipal Utility District (CO); Waverly Power and Light (CO); Electric industry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News Industry: UK unveils plans to tackle climate change
Abstract: The UK Government has published for consultation its draft National Allocation Plan setting out how greenhouse gas emission allowances will be allocated to the operators of UK installations for the first phase of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS), which runs from 2005-2007. The plans will help the government meet its national goal of moving towards a 20% reduction in emissions of CO2 by 2010. The initial allocation of allowances for the first phase of the scheme was consistent with an overall reduction in UK CO2 emissions of 16.3%. However, the overall level of allowances to be allocated in the UK phase 2 of the scheme (which runs from 2008-2012) will be strengthened to be consistent with the trading sector's contribution to achieving the 20% goal. Each EU Member State was required to draw up a National Allocation Plan for submission to the European Commission by the end of March 2004. The Plan has to set out the total number of emission allowances, each representing 1 ton of CO2, to be allocated to the industry sectors covered by the EU ETS.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Maryland; The 2005 ROP plan for the Baltimore severe 1-hour ozone nonattainment area; Revisions to the plan's emissions inventories and motor vehicle emissions budgets to reflect MOBILE6
Abstract: EPA is approving SIP revisions submitted by the State of Maryland. These revisions amend the Baltimore severe 1-hr ozone nonattainment area's (the Baltimore area's) rate-of-progress (ROP) plan for 2005. These revisions update the plan's emission inventories and motor vehicle emissions budgets to reflect the use of MOBILE6 while continuing to demonstrate that the ROP requirement for 2005 will be met. The revisions also amend the contingency measures associated with the 2005 ROP plan. These revisions are being approved in accordance with the Clean Air Act. This final rule is effective on 2/13/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Interim final determination to stay and/or defer sanctions, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: EPA is making an interim final determination to stay and/or defer imposition of sanctions based on a proposed approval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP published elsewhere in today's Federal Register. The revisions concern San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District Rules 4701, 4702, 4703, 4305, 4306, and 4351. This interim final determination is effective on 2/12/2004. However, comments will be accepted until 3/15/2004. The subjects included in 40 CFR Part 52 are environmental protection, air pollution control, intergovernmental regulations, NO2, O3, particulate matter, and reporting and recordkeeping requirements.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Connecticut; Motor vehicle emissions budgets for 2005 and 2007 using MOBILE6.2 for the Connecticut Portion of the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island nonattainment area and for 2007 for the Greater Connecticut nonattainment area
Abstract: The EPA is approving a revision to the Connecticut SIP for the attainment and maintenance of the 1-hr NAAQS for ground level ozone submitted by the State of Connecticut. The intended effect of this action is to approve Connecticut's 2005 and 2007 motor vehicle emissions budgets recalculated using MOBILE6.2 for the Connecticut portion of the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island nonattainment area, and to approve Connecticut's 2007 motor vehicle emissions budgets to the Greater Connecticut nonattainment area also recalculated using MOBILE6.2. This rule is effective on 2/4/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Diesel tech: Diesel meets new regs
Abstract: Mazda Motor Corp., has restyled its Mazda Bongo van and truck range by introducing a newly developed diesel engine, which is designed to reduce greatly the exhaust emissions. The upgraded vehicles are equipped with the new diesel engine and are the first in their class to comply with Japan's New Short-Term Diesel Emissions Regulations and the Automobile NOx/PM Control Law, making them eligible for sale and registration in the major metropolitan areas of Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya. The performance and the fuel economy of this technology also show a significant improvement over the earlier diesel engines that were used in the Bongo series. Additional enhancements for the Bongo van/lineup includes a more powerful gasoline engine, revised seat, door trim fabric, and a driver's seatbelt with pretensioner and load limiter.
Index Keywords: Automotive industry; Emission control; Exhaust systems (engine); Fuel economy; Gasoline; Diesel Emissions; Exhaust emissions; Gasoline engine; Mazda Motor Corp (CO); Diesel engines

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Wood construction wins greenhouse contest
Abstract: State Forests of New South Wales (SFNSW) and the Cooperative Research Center for Greenhouse Accounting (CRCGA) formed a partnership aimed at assessing the storage of carbon in forest products, from the harvesting of trees through production and use of timber products, their time in service and their ultimate disposal in landfills. The research uses new Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) processes to accurately measure the greenhouse gas implications of substituting forest products for alternative materials in house construction. Initial results show that greater use of wood products can reduce the emissions of greenhouse gases associated with house construction.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Forestry; Greenhouse effect; Harvesting; Houses; Life cycle; Timber; Greenhouse gas emissions; Greenhouse gases; House construction; Wooden construction; Carbon Dioxide; Construction Materials; Forestry; Greenhouse Effect; Harvesting; Life Cycle; Lumber; Pollution Control; Trees

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Donaldson To Supply Systems For Buses ... Impco Agreement With Hyundai ... Fuel Cell Power Plant From Caterpillar & Fuel Cell Energy
Abstract: The emerging and alternative technologies for fuel cells, offered by various companies are presented. Donaldson Co. has developed 1100 EPA approved Donaldson Diesel Oxidation Catalyst (DOC) mufflers and Spiracle crankcase filter emission control devices that reduce total engine emission by 50%. Impco Technologies has signed an agreement with Hyundai Heavy Industries of Korea to supply its EPA certified engines with Spectrum fuel system. FuelCell Energy and Caterpillar has signed a contract to supply a 250 kW Direct FuelCell (DFC) power plant to feed power at a substation of the electric distribution system in the City of Westerville. The development of a performance enhancer for fuel cell batteries by Toyo Radiator Co. is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Buses; Catalyst activity; Crankcases; Diesel fuels; Diesel power plants; Electric power distribution; Fuel filters; Fuel systems; Natural gas; Off road vehicles; Oxidation; Particulate emissions; Regulatory compliance; Biodiesel fuels; Caterpillar (CO); Donaldson Co. (CO); Fuel cell power plants; FuelCell Energy (CO); Heesung-Engelhard Corp. (CO); Hyundai Heavy Industries (CO); Impco Technologies (CO); Toyo Radiator Co. (CO); Fuel cells

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Highway, bridge construction advances 25 percent in November
Abstract: The advancements in construction industry in the US in November 2003, regulatory agenda of OSHA, MSHA for 2004, and the initiative of MSHA in digitizing abandoned mine traps are presented. Highway and bridge construction increased by 25% in November 2003, giving an upward impetus to the industry. Nonbuilding construction grew at 11% in November 2003 and it was helped by a 14% increase for school construction. OSHA and MSHA intend to issue rules on asbestos, diesel particulate matter and crystalline silica. Mine Safety and Health administration (MSHA) of the US has granted $3.9 million to 13 states to establish an electronic system of digitizing underground maps for abandoned mines.
Index Keywords: Abandoned mines; Accident prevention; Asbestos; Bridges; Budget control; Construction industry; Digital control systems; Highway systems; Industrial economics; Information management; Miners; Mining laws and regulations; Regulatory compliance; Silica; Sustainable development; Underground structures; Mine mapping; Permissible exposure limit (PEL); Underground mines; Mining

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Fuel cell buses take to London streets
Abstract: The UK's first fuel cell buses took to the streets in January 2004 as part of the Europe-wide Clean Urban Transport in Europe (CUTE) scheme aimed at reducing CO2 emissions from vehicles. Three vehicles are in operation on London's number 25 route, which runs from Ilford in Essex to Oxford Circus. More routes may be added in the near future. Hydrogen will be brought in by tanker in liquid form. The single-decker vehicles were designed by Daimler-Chrysler and can travel ≤ 125 mi in between fuel stops.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Revisions to South Carolina State Implementation Plan: Transportation conformity rule
Abstract: The EPA is approving the SIP revision submitted by the state of South Carolina on 11/19/2003, aimed at establishing specific consultation procedures for the implementation of transportation conformity requirements. This SIP revision also incorporates the state's adoption of the federal transportation conformity regulations verbatim. The transportation conformity rules assure that projected emissions from transportation plans, improvement programs, and projects in air quality stay within the motor vehicle emissions ceiling contained in the SIP. The SIP revision allows the state to implement and enforce the federal transportation conformity requirement at the state level. This action streamlines the conformity process to allow direct consultation among agencies at the local level. This direct final rule is effective on 3/29/2004, unless the EPA receives adverse comments by 3/1/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; New York State implementation plan revision; 1-hour ozone control programs
Abstract: The EPA is approving a revision to the New York SIP for ozone, concerning the control of VOC. The SIP revision consists of amendments to Part 226, "Solvent Metal Cleaning", Part 228, "Surface Coating Processes", Part 235, "Consumer Products", and the adoption of new rule Part 239, "Portable Fuel Container Spillage Control", of Title 6 of the New York Codes, Rules and Regulations. This revision consists of control measures needed to meet the shortfall emissions reduction identified by the EPA in New York's 1-hr ozone attainment demonstration SIP. The aim of this action is to approve control strategies which will reduce emissions and help attain the national ambient air quality standard for ozone. This rule will be effective on 2/23/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revisions to the California State Implementation Plan, San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District, Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District
Abstract: The EPA is approving SIP revisions submitted by the Governor of Montana on 6/26/1997 and 6/13/2000, since these meet the requirements for moderate PM-10 nonattainment areas contained in Part D of the Clean Air Act. These revisions contain an inventory of emissions for Thompson Falls, and establish and require the continuation of all control measures adopted and implemented for reductions of particulate matter with an aerodynamic diameter of ≤ 10 μm (PM10), to meet the PM10 NAAQS. This final rule is effective on 2/23/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Tennessee: Nitrogen oxides budget and allowance trading program
Abstract: The EPA is finalizing the limited approval and limited disapproval of revisions to the San Joaquin Valley Unified Air Pollution Control District and Yolo-Solano Air Quality Management District portion of the California SIP. This action concerns VOC emissions from industries storing, loading, and transferring organic liquids, e.g., LNG or liquefied hazardous gas, as part of their operations under the Clean Air Act. This action simultaneously approves local rules that regulate these emission sources, and directs California to correct rule deficiencies. This rule is effective on 2/23/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: States propose dropped federal rules
Abstract: New Jersey Governor James McGreevey has issued rules mandating tougher power plant emissions reductions for mercury, stricter drinking water standards for arsenic, and reductions in fine particles from diesel engines. McGreevey will require facilities to reduce mercury emissions 90% by 2007. The Environmental Integrity Project issued a report saying that states have been forced to take the lead on reducing air pollution as federal goverment commitment to environmental protection has lapsed. The project stated that its evidence shows that the nation will have to rely on state actions to achieve emissions reductions.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Codes (standards); Diesel engines; Environmental protection; Gas emissions; Mercury (metal); Potable water; Project management; Public policy; Drinking water standards; Emissions reduction; Environmental Integrity Project; Federal government; Laws and legislation

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Revision to the California State Implementation Plan, Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: The EPA is taking direct final action to approve a revision to the Monterey Bay Unified Air Pollution Control District portion of the California SIP. The revision concerns VOC emissions from the transfer of gasoline at dispensing stations. A local rule will be approved that regulates this emission source under the Clean Air Act. This rule is effective on 3/15/2004, unless the EPA receives adverse comments by 2/17/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environmental News: States take lead on climate change laws
Abstract: To budge the federal government, nearly a dozen states filed a petition in the US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on 10/23/2003, asking the court to review the Bush Administration's August 2003 decision that the Clean Air Act does not give EPA the authority to regulate emissions of CO2. At least 16 states have passed laws known as the "renewable portfolio standards" that require power plants to generate a certain percentage of their total electricity output from renewable resources, e.g., wind and solar power, according to Judy Greenwald, program director with the Pew Center on Global Climate Change. Renewable portfolio standards have been contentious on the federal level because sometimes renewable power sources can be more costly than fossil fuels. On another front, 11 states have implemented or are developing CO2 registries, two of which are mandatory, according to the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management. In 2003, the state launched a registry for utilities and any Wisconsin firm to voluntarily report reductions of CO2 or any other greenhouse gas, according to officials with the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources. Other state actions include creating tax incentives to build refueling sites for vehicles using alternative fuels, improving mass transit systems, and launching energy conservation programs for homes and businesses.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Adequacy status of the Greeley, Colorado, carbon monoxide revised maintenance plan for transportation conformity purposes
Abstract: EPA is notifying the public that it has found that the motor vehicle emissions budgets in the Greeley, CO, carbon monoxide revised maintenance plan that was submitted by the Governor on 6/20/2003 are adequate for conformity purposes. On 3/2/99, the DC Circuit Court ruled that budgets in submitted SIP cannot be used for conformity determinations until EPA has affirmatively found them adequate. As a result of the finding, the North Front Range Transportation & Air Quality Planning Council, the City of Greeley, the Colorado Department of Transportation and the DOT are required to use the motor vehicle emissions budgets from this submitted maintenance plan for future conformity determinations. This finding is effective 1/20/2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Business update: Joint ventures and alliances: ClearAir plus creates China network
Abstract: ClearAir Plus LLC has signed agreements with several Chinese enterprises to implement the firm's ClearAir Plus technology throughout China. ClearAir is a fuel precombustion catalyst that works with virtually every internal-combustion engine, reducing emissions of particulates by 60%, hydrocarbons by 40%, CO by 20%, and NOx by 22%. ClearAir Plus technology will positively impact air quality in Beijing, where officials promised to retrofit 90% of the city's 118,000 mass-transit bus fleets before the 2008 Summer Olympics.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Washington perspective: Settlement means Citgo will upgrade refinery
Abstract: Citgo Refining and Chemical Co, L.P., Tulsa, OK, and the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality have agreed to resolve longstanding disputes concerning environmental requirements at Citgo's refinery in Corpus Christi, TX. Under the settlement agreement, Citgo will make numerous capital improvements to upgrade the performance of its Corpus Christi operations, including a new off-gas treatment unit in the sulfur recovery area of the East Plant; a third-stage separator in a catalytic cracking unit; additional controls in the wastewater treatment facilities to remove oil from water; and new and modified scrubbers to reduce emissions from flaring. The total cost of the investments covered by the agreement is estimated to be over $20 million. As another component of its settlement of the TCEQ enforcement actions, Citgo will make an $870,000 contribution to the state's general revenue fund, and an equal contribution to the Corpus Christi Air Monitoring and Surveillance Project.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News: Hydrogenics in FCV deal with Purolator, wins US Navy contract
Abstract: In Canada, Hydrogenics has received a contract from Purolator Courier to develop and deploy a fuel cell hybrid delivery van and an on-site hydrogen refueling system. The deal is part of Purolator's "Greening the Fleet" initiative to explore the use of clean transportation technologies in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from its delivery fleet. This refueling station will be commissioned at one of Purolator's depots in the Greater Toronto area, where it will potentially become one part in the region's emerging hydrogen refueling infrastructure. Hydrogenics has also been selected to provide a PEM hydrogen refueler for the US Navy's Naval Surface Warfare Center's (NSWC) test facility in Crane, IN. Under the terms of the contract, Hydrogenics will supply a fully integrated, compact HyLYZER refueler capable of producing and dispensing 2 kg/day of high purity compressed hydrogen. NSWC Crane expected to take delivery of the unit in middle of March 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Gas turbine excels in meeting remote TransCanada test
Abstract: The remote Nordegg natural gas compressor station is home to a unique gas turbine pilot project co-managed by the energy business of Rolls-Royce and TransCanada Pipeline Co. Their working relationship is allowing Rolls-Royce to test and prove the RB211-6761 aero-derivative gas turbine in a challenging environment. Rolls-Royce and TransCanada are evaluating power, heat rate, emissions, vibration levels, and reliability across the full speed range of the RB211-6761. The gas turbine produced an exceptional reduction of exhaust emissions. When compared to the previous unit on site, the new gas turbine produced 82% fewer NOx emissions or those most commonly associated with smog in urban areas. The unit's fuel efficiency means less CO2 is also produced. TransCanada has > 100 Rolls-Royce gas turbines on its 39,000-km pipeline network.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Australia: Howard government backs geosequestration
Abstract: The Howard government's energy statement focuses on research into geosequestration but critics claim the Australian government has failed to adequately support the development of clean energy solutions. The government will provide $(Aust)500 million starting in 2006 for industry-led projects to lower Australia's greenhouse emissions. The funding will support technologies that have the potential to reduce greenhouse emissions by ≥ 2% and be commercially available between 2020 and 2030. The energy statement cited coal-fired electricity generation with geosequestration, the storage of CO2 in geological formation, as a key technology to be developed. Peter Cook, CEO of Cooperative Research Center for Greenhouse Gas Technologies, welcomed the government's interest in geosequestration. The process involves the capture, separation, transport, and injection of CO2 into geological structures at depths of ≥ 800 m. The government statement provides $(Aust)100 million for the development of renewable technologies and $(Aust)75 million to support "solar cities" trials.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Analysis: Kyoto edges into force
Abstract: The Kyoto Protocol on greenhouse gas emissions (e.g., CO2) is on the verge of reaching the critical mass of global acceptance that is required to see it enter into force, following a somewhat reluctant acceptance of the document by the Russian government. With the backing of President Vladimir Putin and his cabinet, the pact must now go before the State Duma who will pass the final verdict on whether or not Russia will undertake the emissions curbs outlined in Kyoto. If the Russians complete the ratification process and all the acceptance criteria are met, the document will enter into force 90 days later.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Emissions dogfighting starts as Europe's NAP deadline looms
Abstract: The tensions arising because of the European Commission's deadline for national allocation plans (NAP) required under Emissions Trading legislation for the 15 member states is discussed. The deadline for the implementation is March 31, 2004. However, intensive discussions are taking place between the government and industry over the economic effects of the implementation of these legislations. The EU is facing criticism for its Kyoto policies regarding control of greenhouse emissions from member states and the Spanish Government.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Economic and social effects; Greenhouse effect; International cooperation; Laws and legislation; Public policy; Emissions trading; Greenhouse emissions; Industrial emissions

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The U.S. composite market - A view from AXEL Plastics Research Laboratories
Abstract: The US composite market is faced with the challenge of meeting the increased local and federal regulation concerning emissions of volatile organic compound (VOC). In view of this development, industry suppliers are offering new products such as gelcoats and low-VOC resins to meet regulatory limit. But these new products provide both opportunity and challenge to US composite manufacturers. The advent of low-VOC resin formulations offers various problems which are generally attributed to mould release. AXEL Plastics Research Laboratories USA, a supplier of mould releases and resin process aid additives, has responded to these new industrial demands by offering semi-permanent mould releases with excellent chemical resistance and surface properties designed to enhance wet-out of gelcoats. AXEL has specially formulated internal mould releases that does not impact cross linking and cure kinetics. Besides, these neutralized internal mould release formulations do not interact with the molecular sieves that are frequently incorporated in polyols as drying agents.
Index Keywords: composites industry; emission reduction; pollution control; regulation; volatile organic compound

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Top of the news: Study: EPA underreporting toxic emissions
Abstract: According to a study released on 6/22/2004, EPA and state governments appear to be underreporting refinery and chemical plant toxic air emissions in the "startling magnitude" of ≥ 330 million lb/yr. The study was commissioned by the Environmental Integrity Project and the Galveston Houston-Association for Smog Prevention (EIP-GHASP). The EIP-GHASP analysis finds that the presence of the carcinogens benzene and butadiene in the air in the US may be 4-5 times higher than the level the EPA reports to the public. The study, which is based on findings by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, applies the commissions findings on the underreporting of certain toxic emissions nationwide and concludes that ≥ 16% of toxic air emissions from all sources "have been kept off the books". EIP-GHASP study noted that the EPA has knowingly underreported the air pollution data in its annual TRI data for years.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Safety-Environment. Insufficient measures to attain the goals of the EU in the matter of greenhouse gas emissions [Sécurité-Environnement. Des mesures insuffisantes pour atteindre les objectifs de l'UE en matière d'émissions de gaz à effet de serre]
Abstract: New projections gathered by the European Agency for the Environment indicate that based on policies and measures put into operation or expected up to the present, the EU and many of its state members will not succeed to respect the objectives of the Kyoto protocol in the matter of greenhouse gas emissions. The excessive increase of emissions from transport and especially road transport is the main reason. These projections, however, do not take into consideration the expected effects of a number of measures developed within the framework of the European program on climate change directed by the European Commission. Among these, there is the market for rights with respect to greenhouse gas emissions that is to begin in 2005. It is the exchange of these rights that is expected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 8% avg and that will represent an upheaval in European companies and especially in industry. The 15 EU countries are obliged to reduce the total level of six greenhouse gases that are considered as contributing to climate changes of 8% above their 1990 levels from now to 2008-2012. An internal agreement for dividing the load imposes equally on each member state reaching the individual goal the obligation to limit or reduce its national emissions. The discussion covers the very pessimistic projections; query whether the trading of emissions rights is the ideal solution; and the transport sector as being responsible for over a fifth of the greenhouse gas emissions in the EU, posing the greatest challenge to the Kyoto objectives.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy. The white paper [Energie. Le Livre Blanc]
Abstract: A report covers several extracts from the White Paper presented by N. Fontaine (Ministry of Industry) in November 2003. The topics include introduction; the place of energy in the economy and society; the demand for energy; the reserves of petroleum and gas; the placement of renewable energies; the advantages of choosing nuclear energy in terms of national independence and the production of energy with weak CO2 emissions; the four priority goals of the energy policy of France; and the energy policy as having to lean on concrete and operational measures. After the first oil shock France developed a policy of energy saving and of developing nuclear energy, creating energy independence and generating competitive electricity. Also, France today is in a better energy position than some other countries in the struggle against climatic change. The challenge today relates to greenhouse gas emissions. The scorching heat of the summer 2003 is but one omen among others. The second challenge is to develop an energy policy that takes into account the development of economic realities, or tensions, that will inevitably occur in the world. In several decades the production of oil and gas will plateau and will be concentrated in the hands of a few states the geopolitical stability of which may be uncertain. Also, the economic growth of demographic giants like China and India will inevitably lead to a growth in consumption, considerable but legitimate, and reconcilable with difficulty with the stagnation of production without having consequences on the price of energy and the inevitable increase in greenhouse gas emissions. To stand up to these challenges, the reduction in the greenhouse gas emissions in France by a factor of four times between now and 2050 and the development of competing energy sources also responding to the growth in world demand as well as the exigencies of security of supply, are thus imperatives to which the energy policy will contribute. Four goals should thus guide the action of France, i.e., the guarantee of the right of access to energy for all citizens; the struggle against global warming; the preservation of an element of national independence to limit the impact of tensions to come in the oil market; and the maintenance of a competitive energy in France. IEA estimates that based on a growth of 1.8%/yr, global emissions of CO2 due to use of energy might reach 38 billion ton of CO2 in 2030, which is 70% higher than that of 2000.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Cogeneration. Proposition of the European Commission for cogeneration [Cogénération. Proposition de la commission européenne pour la cogénération]
Abstract: The green paper on the security of supply of energy published in 2000 signaled the need to limit energy dependence of the European Union and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. However, emissions of CO2 in the EU are increasing which creates difficulties with respect to engagements with the Kyoto protocol. The generation of electricity by cogeneration represented 11% of the total generation of electricity of the EU in 1998. If part of the cogeneration in the generation of electricity would increase to 18%, the savings in energy would represent ∼ 3-4% of the basic energy consumption of the EU. Cogeneration economizes energy and improves the security of supply. Cogeneration decreases losses in grid energy because cogeneration power plants are closer to the areas of consumption in general. A cogeneration plant for electricity and heat functions thanks to turbines or gas engines. Natural gas is the most common energy used in cogeneration plants. However, renewable energies and wastes can also be used. In contrast to a traditional electric power plants where the flue gases go directly to the chimney, in cogeneration the flue gases are first cooled, ceding their energy to a hot water/steam circuit. Cogeneration plants can achieve ∼ 90% energy efficiency. The process is more ecological because natural gas liberates less CO2 and NOx than oil or coal. The development of cogeneration could avoid the emissions of 127 million ton of CO2 in the EU in 2010 and 258 million ton in 2020. The EC proposes to promote the installation of cogeneration plants where there is a demand for one or where a demand is expected to develop. In the short term, the directive reinforces existing cogeneration plants and promotes new ones. In the long term the directive creates the framework needed for a highly efficient cogeneration plant to reduce emissions of CO2 and other substances, contributing to sustainable development. There are now examples in some member states of regulated development, such as in Belgium (green certificates and cogeneration quotas), in Spain (new decree on the sale of cogenerated electricity), and in Germany (new law on cogeneration). The directive proposes direct public aid on electricity produced in small facilities of < 50 Mw and in large facilities for their first 50Mw generated. The dates of co-decision are cited beginning on 7/22/2002, then 5/13/2003, 7/23-24/2003, and 9/8/2003.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The European Union could save 202 billion kw-hr per year thanks to more efficient industrial motors [L'Union européene pourrait économiser chaque année 202 milliards de kWh, grâce à des moteurs industriels plus performants]
Abstract: A study published at the initiative of the European Copper Institute under the aegis of the Motor Challenge Program of the European Commission states that with use of more efficient motors in industry in the EU, 202 billion kw-hr/yr could be saved. The study was made public at the 9th session of the parties to the Convention of the UN on climate change (COP9). However, a voluntary policy on the part of public bodies will allow the effective realization of this formidable potential to save energy. Over 60% of the electricity consumed in European industries is due to systems run by electric motors. In improving their yield of useful energy, European industry could consume less electricity and avoid emitting 79 million ton/yr of CO2. This represents < 25% of the European involvement in the framework of the Kyoto protocol on the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. This is equivalent to 1.8 billion sq m of solar roofs. The bill in terms of environmental costs to society would be relieved by €6 billion/yr. The industry would save €15-20 billion/yr. In certain cases, savings in energy could amount to ≤ 50% thanks to the investment in more efficient motors. Saving 202 billion kw-hr/yr of electricity would also avoid the construction in Europe of 30 power plants of greater output to respond to the constantly increasing demand of the need for electricity. This would also mean 6% less of European imports of electricity. It remains to public bodies to put together an assembly of diversified measures associating regulations, financial incentives, and information campaigns to sensitize the industrial world. The cost of such an action would be €400 million. Increasing the amount of copper in the electric motors, transformers, and electrical lines can reduce by ≤ 70% energy losses and improve the yield of energy. Copper is the best electrical conductor among the non-precious metals. Installation of timers to avoid running at night, installation of electronic speed controllers, and the replacement of motors that are too powerful for the needs required are other examples of saving energy.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Global monitor: Duck, duck... juice!
Abstract: We Energies has been purchasing renewable energy from Wisconsin's first fully operational duck manure-to-energy digester at Maple Leaf Farms in Racin County. The farm uses the abundant and free supply of CH4 from a duck biowaste plant to fuel a 20-kw on-site cogeneration system from Hess Microgen. The farm used to flare the CH4 produced by the anaerobic digester to comply with a mandate to reduce the state's emissions of greenhouse gases. Now, the CH4 powers the cogeneration plant. Some energy is needed to heat the digester, which runs continuously to 104°F, but other than that, the digester consumes no energy resources. After the digestion process is complete, the odorless solids remaining are removed and packaged for sale as fertilizer.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Carbon fibre: A new player enters the scene
Abstract: The China Worldbest Group Co (CWGC) is going to start up its polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and carbon-fiber production plant at Benghu, in the Anhui province in Eastern China, in April 2005. The plant consists of raw-material storage and preparation, and batch polymerization processing by the conversion of acrylonitrile monomer into polyacrylonitrile. The polymerized product is spun into a yarn and further processed, and then dried to form PAN precursor. Anhui Huawan Carbon Fiber Co, a subsidiary of the Shanghai Worldbest Investment Development Co, of the CWGC group, will be China's first PAN producer, and in the initial stage of the project, the target is set to 200 tons of carbon fiber and 500 tons of Protonema. The investment in the plant is due to an active market and increasing demand for carbon fiber in China, where it is used mainly in leisure products, sports utilities, general industrial areas, oceanic oil-field utilities, and both civil and military aerospace applications.
Index Keywords: carbon fiber; company information; polyacrylonitrile; textile industry
